headline: Chaotic, but with a lot of opportunity
pros:
A decentralized team structure means lots of opportunity for movement and upward growth. It's easy to pick up new skills on the job.

Most of the people I've worked with here are talented, intelligent, and a pleasure to work with.
cons:
Re-orgs happen frequently (though those are not usually accompanied by layoffs) A decentralized team structure also contributes to the general chaos caused by re-orgs, and we often pivot on priorities. Work gets done twice by two different teams, or gets done once and then thrown away, etc. 

I've rarely gotten the chance to fully finish/polish tools I've worked on, often being forced to move onto the next big thing, which in turn also never gets fully finished. 

Some teams are also noticeably less competent than others, and it's implicitly expected (and sometimes necessary) for more competent teams to give others direction or pick up the slack.

headline: Worst Experience of Career
pros: - If you aren’t looking to challenge or strain yourself then you’ve found the right place. You can achieve an amazing work life balance. Especially if you don’t tie any of your self worth to your career.
cons:
- All the good coworkers/managers I knew have chosen to leave at some point or another due to entrenched politics seemingly designed by unqualified people to keep themselves employed
- In my experience, there was a poor understanding of how to measure success, leading to most software initiatives failing. This also leads to most new initiatives being a complete shot in the dark. 
- Leaders I worked with seemed to be in place solely based on tenure. At other companies I have worked at, I don’t think they would have met the bar.
- In my career, I had never experienced those situations you see on HR training videos. The toxic environment created here really put me to the test on those.
- Compensation is lackluster. The equity given had such a long time until realization that they might as well not even offer it.

headline: My Review working as a Graphic Designer at Cimpress India Pvt. Ltd for almost 2 years
pros: When you are selected for Cimpress you feel really good and happy with all the amenities they provide you with. You will get a nice PC to work on, good work environment, lots of facilities.
cons:
The salary is extremely low, not even 15k INR/Month for two years of experience and work life balance is not there. work is just not appealing and team leads just put pressure on you to complete the targets. All you can expect from this company after getting selected is a lot of pressure to complete targets on time, NOTHING creative work here, I repeat, no work is creative there. One should think before joining this company because even after you have worked for 1.5 or 2 years at Cimpress you are still a fresher outside as you don't have any practical knowledge as a graphic designer, all you were doing is just completing targets. I think they should not fool job seekers who want a graphic designer role but end up just completing targets everyday. They should mention that its a post to complete targets not a graphic design post.
The salary is the biggest drawback working here, they provide such a low salary and don't give any bonuses ever. All you will get is parties on major Indian festivals. Not a good place to start your graphic design career, especially if you want to grow and learn something for real than DO NOT join this company. Some of the team leads are arrogant and don't have any knowledge apart from how to terrorize employees and complete targets.

headline: High growth and truly open work culture
pros:
- High growth opportunities
- Flexible tech stack
- Best work culture
- Zero politics
- Humble leaders
- No need to worry about inflation
- Great hikes if you perform well
- Talent is valued not your college tag
- Best Remote-First policy
- Open to critical feedback
- Global team collaboration opportunities
- Your work has high impact on many small and local businesses worldwide.
- Most managers and leaders are developers themselves from whom you can learn a lot.

Disclaimer: Views are my own and based on the teams I work with.
cons:
- Way too diverse. Every team is different. So flexibility on tech stack and types of project you get will depend on your team's combined decision.
- People work too much voluntarily.
- No training period. If you need to be spoon fed everything then you will have a hard time here.
- Most problems that we solve on day-to-day work do not require DSA (in my team) So you may not enjoy work if you are DSA fan.

headline: Indeed an equal opportunity employer

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good pay, decent benefits, but most importantly, company and management cares about lower level engineers and their growth. You can immediately see the impact of your work. Teams are somewhat semi-independent which makes for less uncertainty.
cons:
Possibly less/no growth after lead engineer level unless you're hired at that level, and/or in a team with those opportunities, but if you're lower than that, this is a good company to get there.

A little hands-off that you learn by making trying and making mistakes but there is room for error. If you don't enjoy that and want constant technical feedback - maybe not the place for you

headline: Trying to be a tech company but failing constantly
pros:
- Benefits are okay but do not compare to any big tech company.
- Great work/life balance.
- Lots of personal and team autonomy.
- Great tech if you know what you are doing.
- Some people are really nice but most of them left or are leaving.
- I was lucky to be in a great team.
cons:
- Lots of tools have changed but not because of quality/productivity concerns but rather for cost or just because this is "cool" now.
- Politics are a big thing in this company, from the lowest level up. People are not rewarded based on their performance.
- Speaking of performance, the rating was always flawed, nobody in this company could explain what needs to be done in order to get top marking. It was "reserved".
- Taking responsibility is not something common here. That's how bloated organisations with lots of people appeared but only about 20% would actually deliver.
- They always look at other big tech companies and try copying them but it never works out, I believe because the culture and experience is rather different here.
- Incompetent people were kept around (because line above) and as a consequence lots of people decided to leave.
- Interviewing questions are 15 years old in this company, that should tell you something.
- There is no plan in place to grow people anymore though that was a big concern in the old company, Vistaprint.
- CTO is highly inexperienced and not prepared to give a direction inside the company from a tech perspective.
- Vistaprint is a very customer focused company while Cimpressed lacks a lot in that regard.
- There would be employees encouraging other employees to put positive feedback here because the rating of the company is going down.
- Brilliant engineers fail to be recognized, while mediocre people are.

headline: Good culture & people, lots of reorgs
pros:
-Great people
-Good work/life balance
-Great perks (including food trucks, sabbaticals, generous PTO)
-Challenging work, and never bored
-Overall great culture, and most managers have an open door policy that you feel 100% comfortable exercising
cons:
-Reorganizations have become the norm, and this makes for what feels to be an unstable work environment.  Just when you get comfortable with your current situation, something with change that changes your job.
-Management doesn't always recognize your hardwork.  When you go above and beyond, you will not be rewarded.  Staff will end up doing the work of a manager without any recognition.
-Management doesn't always want to hear the opinions of the staff which their decisions affect. 
-Not always a clear path for growth opportunities in your career.

headline: Decent company, but exodus of technical talent
pros:
- Work-life balance heavily favors life. 
- Benefits/salary are on the lower end for a quality tech company, but definitely in the quality tech range 
- Lots of competent people are leaving - plenty of responsibility and promotions up for grabs
- Lots of team autonomy. Experience varies by team. There are some really smart people doing really interesting work - it's just hard to find
- Excellent CTO trying to build a high-quality tech company. 
- Tech stack is pretty modern. Very few legacy systems following transition to microservices
- Every 5 years, you earn a month-long sabbatical.
cons:
- Good people leaving constantly. It's an exodus draining the company of talent
- Rampant dead-sea effect. Long-time Vistaprint/Cimpress-ers getting influence beyond abilities as everyone else leaves. Frustrating the young talent away
- Some feeling that the long-term strategy has been abandoned in favor of driving the stock price up after several quarters of disappointing stock price growth
- Equity offering is poor
- No peer reviews. Incompetent, politically-savvy people can find a niche and stay there
- Waltham is being diminished in favor of cheaper overseas workers
- Endless reorgs and layoffs. Good that leadership is willing to acknowledge mistakes, but no stability.
- Vision is unclear. Not sure if we're still building a platform or if it would just be too embarrassing to abandon the name Mass Customization Platform

headline: Good Company but not for Long term
pros:
Culture is has been very good until  recently when things are changing drastically.
Work From home facility. Flexible work timings.
Technical stack is awesome.
cons:
Some projects have poor leaders. They lack vision and proper direction.
People are good but there are some which make this company a political zone.
Not sure where the company is heading and if it will be successful enough.
Salary trends are dropping.
People are hired by promising onsite opportunities but there are none log term. If you are lucky enough , you may travel for a week or two.

headline: Progressive culture, autonomy and tools to get things done
pros: Technology roles are highly-valued and given wide latitude to accomplish business objectives. Flexible work hours including work from home. Very decentralized. Few meetings.
cons:
Many reorgs over the past few years has been disorienting, but that seems to have abated lately. 
Very difficult to find out what other teams are doing and how that may impact what you do. 
Boston office is being de-emphasized in lieu of lower-cost remote sites.

headline: Was better in the past but frequent reorgs and lack of direction
pros: If you get in on the right team or under right manager, you could find a good niche.   Good benefits - solid insurance, free food pretty often, parking gym game room, good 401k match.
cons: Lots of reorgs and layoffs, seemingly without a rhyme or reason. Too many politics.  Gating factors on decisions are politics involving long time Vistaprint-ers/Cimpress-ers.  Lack of ownership for failed strategies from the top, just reorg and let some people go.  Redoing team structures does not make up for bad business decisions or initiatives.

headline: I guess if you really need a job...
pros:
- Competitive salary and benefits; not top-tier anymore, but reasonably good
- Nice campus in Waltham; free garage parking, on-site gym, reasonably priced cafeteria with healthy options.
- If you're somewhat political and know how to keep your head down, you can collect a decent salary for doing next to nothing; just be ready to find another job quickly.
cons:
- Constant reorganization and head cutting.  Really, no one in this organization enjoys any semblance of job security any more, regardless of performance or seniority.
- No clear business strategy other than keeping the stock price up.
- No technical strategy, discipline or leadership.  As it is, the software architecture is an undocumented mash-up of buzz-word technologies with nothing quite finnished or working as intended; hysterical amounts of tech-debt.  
- Very unsatisfying work for those who like to build things.  Given the recent cuts, most engineers spend their time cleaning up other people's messes and getting ready for their next gig.

headline: Best place to work

headline: Intern

headline: Great benefits but frequent restructures
pros:
Benefits/Perks are great. BCBS health provider with different options (high deductible + HSA, PPO, HMO with low deductible), 401k matching with good fund options (low fees, Roth and traditional 401k options), twice monthly free lunch and every 3 weeks pizza for technologists, 3 week starting PTO with an additional day every year up to 4 week total, 4 floating holidays a year and 8 company holidays, 4 week paid sabbatical every 5 years of service.

Great work life balance. Many people have opportunity to work from home. Some work remotely full time (or very close to full time). 6-8 week (can't confirm the exact time given) Maternity/full-time care giver leave (100% paid with optional long term disability insurance) or 2 week paternity/part time leave. Flexible work schedule (Come in, do your work, work 40 hours a week more a less, make up time if you feel you need to/work less next week if you put in more hours. Figure it out, you're an adult)
cons: Frequent restructures cause layoffs. Seemingly poor performing teams and organizations are not dealt with. Middle to upper-mid management losing touch with individual contributors. Management provide false sense of empowerment, all real decisions happen above sphere of influence. Career growth potential uncertain above middle level.

headline: Cannot recommend
pros: They offer competitive salaries and many job perks to keep people happy while there. Senior leadership is extremely smart and talented. Ample opportunities to jump around and get involved in different projects.
cons: Vistaprint funds the Cimpress strategy and as profits go down, so does Cimpress. Vistaprint is maturing as a business so Cimpress needs to make it on it's own but does not have the people to do so. There are plenty of technology jobs in Boston with growing companies: take one of them.

headline: Downward spiral that could be reversed if management would wake up
pros: A good place to work, but only if you're fresh out of school and want to get some experience working at a big company on a large base of software. You might get lucky and land in a good squad - although there are fewer of them these days (the overall level of talent has gone down).
cons: It used to be a good technology company, but years of constantly reorganizing has silenced or removed the managers who understand software.  What's left are the ladder-climbers. Cimpress has made some business gambles in the last few years that haven't paid off. Now the individual business units are under pressure to improve their numbers and the business leaders have lost patience waiting for the tech organization to fix the software. Feeling the pressure, the tech organization is doing short-term work to patch over deeper problems, which is making the software worse. All this happens under the guise of being Agile. The current tech leaders may be aware that this is happening, but they are more interested in not getting fired than in giving an unpopular message to their business counterparts.

headline: Great work and colleagues, you have to thrive amid change though
pros: More than five years in now and still enjoying the challenge. You have to roll with the changes as the company evolves, but the environment, colleagues, great pay and benefits and challenging work make it worthwhile. It's like a $2bn revenue start-up. Responsibility and progression is there for you if you grab it.
cons: Still a young company and moving pretty fast, so can be hard to keep up with everything that's going on.

headline: Good Intent, Poor Execution
pros: Best-in-class benefits and compensation package,  Highly entrepreneurial environment, Agile mindset
cons: Using "Agile" as an excuse for poor decision-making and mediocre execution, the local managers in Manila say that they themselves are not convinced Agile is the way to go when talking to supervisors, but they say otherwise when talking to agents/design artists,  the culture is not what it seems on the outside.

headline: Cimpress
pros: Culture is great and pay is great
cons: Tends to reorganize internally often

headline: Great Perks, but Lacking Vision/Silo Mentality
pros:
Perks and benefits are definitely the main reasons to join: 
- Health insurance premiums have been increasing every year, but they offer multiple plans (HDHP, HMO, PPO) and it's still a pretty good deal. 
- Free lunch twice a month (food trucks during the summer months).
- Garage parking (no need to sweep off your car or worry about entering into an oven in the summer).
cons:
The company is confused about its vision and the culture depends largely on the business and team.
- As a result of the strategy constantly shifting, reorganizations and turnover are a certainty. FYI - there’s been at least one reorg every year I’ve worked here. 
- Working in finance, I have yet to find a company that has a good work/life balance and this place is no different.  Long hours are to be expected during the close and budget cycles. The difference between here and other companies is that the constant reorgs extend these hours even more so. 
- There is a persistent culture of scapegoating – I’ve seen many smart people that were let go just because they were in the wrong department at the wrong time. Guess what? Just cause the strategy has pivoted doesn’t mean the underlying problem has gone away. The problem just shifts to another department where it will take even longer to figure out because everyone who understood the context was let go.   
- The culture in teams and departments will vary – Corporate culture is more cut-throat whereas if you’re in a revenue generating business, the people tend to be friendlier.

headline: Director
pros: Exciting, fast paced that feels energized and focused on doing something that's never been done before...Outstanding benefits, perks and work environment.  A truly global company so you are exposed to a variety of cultures.

- dynamics sometimes involve changes of focus and lead to the discarding of work
- a recent reduction in scope reduced jobs not related to software engineering and resulted in a narrowed scope

headline: Almost great company for Software Developers
pros: After seeing all the negative comments regarding Cimpress, I think I should provide my input as an employee. After spending 5 years, I believe that Technology/Software development teams in Cimpress are managed well. They provide the necessary environment and freedom for employees to improve themselves and learn new/cool stuff. One can use almost any programming language to build microservices which is completely independent of the rest of the legacy technology stack.
cons: Compensation is not as high as other tech companies. There is no fair policy for people who are doing similar jobs. As an employee, you have to ask for a better compensation constantly. Upper management won't give it to you just because you are performing well / getting good reviews from your peers.

headline: Software Tester
pros:
Good Projects
Growth opportunities
Technical and smart people
cons: None except too many Re-orgs.

headline: Change is the Lifeblood of Technology
pros: Very fast paced, with exciting work.  Teams can work on anything they want with the technology they want.  Frequent reorganizations keep the business focused on what is important instead of languishing in the past.  When change needs to happen management ensures that it does.  Good work is usually rewarded, and Cimpress gives teams and team members the power and responsibility to drive the company forward by pushing decisions down to where the information is.  At Cimpress it is every team members job to determine what is best for the company, no one will tell you what to do, or how to do it, but instead they'll win you over with why.
cons: Like working for any company for a long time, some fellow employees become adjusted to certain level of entitlement.  It unfortunately takes many reorganizations to get everyone back on track and motivated again.

headline: Change is good but not when there are no stable periods
pros:
Learning to adapt to constant change
Able to work on projects/tasks you want due to alot of holes needing to be fixed
Decisions now made by departmental heads rather than a corporate entity
cons:
Political environment:
Lack of employee respect:
Progression seems to occur alot by who you know and favouritism
Apart from change (and a lot of it) unsure what the Company culture is

headline: Lack of respect towards the employee
pros:
Great colleagues, many talented people
Work/Life Balance
Nice offices
cons:
Constant reorganizations
Lack of real respect for employees 
Politics play a major role in the company organization

headline: Great place! Great ppl
pros: Very innovative company. Freedom to explore your interests and pursue what you want.
cons: Frequent management shakeups due to constant change and growth.

headline: Need to be Flexible
pros: Growing company, a lot going on, many opportunities, truly global
cons: Strategies are not thought through enough, and implemented before tested at a smaller scale.

headline: Profit is more important than product/people
pros: Lots of challenging work. You will grow in whatever you do in your time working at Cimpress.
cons: Middle management cares little for their employees. Upper management is more focused on profit than actual products and services. Constant re-orgs and corporate shifts leave an overall sense of instability and uncertainty in the future of the company.

headline: Expendable, you could say
pros:
Free food
Nice office and perks
Some smart colleagues
cons:
Loyalty for value-added contributors (none)
Politics
Reorgs (latest was very large and impacted many people)

headline: Big benefits, big risk
pros:
Salary and compensation
Great people to work with (talented and passionate)
Work-life balance
cons:
Too many re-org changes
Very unstable and volatile

headline: Very disappointing
pros: The people I worked with are very talented and want to see the company do well.
cons: Beware of this company. They clearly don't care about their employees.  They view them as expendable. Organizational changes occur every 3-6 months and this last change impacted ~160 people.

headline: Good place to work/good summer job for students
pros:
- easy work
- nice people
- ample overtime opportunities
- good benefits
- encourages input and new ideas from employees
cons:
- busy periods can get stressful
- management can sometimes be pressing
- lower pay
- not too flexible on work hours (standard shifts)

headline: Management
pros: Great company with vision and innovation
cons: Starting to lose the entrepreneurial fiber and becomes bureaucratic sometimes

headline: Excellent company for technical people
pros:
There are many to tell.  It is a company for technical people where one gets to work on new technologies. 
Also one is responsible for the entire module right till deployment.  A company that believes in the skills and people. Also one gets a chance to work with talented people and learn a lot. 
The best part is the pull model wherein people are motivated to learn new things and ask questions. 
And yes very good  work life balance. 
Work during office hours. 
Great company.
cons: None till date that I say  about

headline: Supply chain intern
pros:
learnt many things
good manager
great environment
cons: too mach structural changes at cimpress

headline: Good Company to work in
pros: Passionate and young people, Flexible and dynamic organization with great opportunities of professional growth.
cons: Complicated relationship with corporate teams, scale gives less flexibility and innovation possibilities to the entire organization. Centralization is not giving the advantage to move fast but is  adding complexity that could be solved with a different structure and some key people.

headline: Former employee
pros: great location. They treated their employees well. They would offer free lunch and breakfast.
cons: There is no career growth. They only focus on software develop not many analyst position.

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: Get to meet new people
cons: This is not my field of study

headline: Software Developer
pros:
Awesome company to work for if you are technically oriented and look to grow yourself on the technical side.
Flexible working hours
Quality driven rather than deadline driven
You get a change to work with some great minds and work on technically challenging stuff
Frequent travel
Start up culture
Awesome culture that is not hierarchical and you have the freedom to try all that you want.
Decision making lies at the ground level and people working are the people making decisions.
cons: You have to keep yourself updated on the trending technologies and keep trying to improve the system.

headline: Associate Accountant
pros: Great exposure to a multitude of finance and accounting activities right away. The team has a lot of hard working, smart but also fun individuals.
cons: Easy to get into the same routine and not have the opportunities to excel in your career.

headline: An excellent place to continue your career
pros:
Cimpress has great benefits such as an on-site gym, crackers and popcorn for snacks, Keurig coffee and teas, water, seltzer, juices, and sodas for drinks.  The on-site cafeteria is decent and reasonably priced.  There is a social gathering that takes place every other week where a fun selection of food is served as well as a nice selection of beers.  There is a game room with pool, table tennis, video games, and air hockey.  There is a dry cleaning service on-site as well.

Most of the people you work with at Cimpress are competent and have a desire to make the workplace awesome.  Many are also social and have decent communication skills.  Furthermore, most employees are able to work together to help each other out for the greater good.
cons: Management and sub-culture within Cimpress varies drastically.  This is good and bad as you may end up in a group that isn't a good fit for you.  Furthermore, is seems as if some groups are behind best practices and it is difficult to penetrate these groups unless there is a leadership change or a revelation that occurs within leadership.  The upside of all of this is that Cimpress is a highly mobile company and you are able to move within Cimpress to other sub-organizations.

headline: Amazing company, Amazing people!
pros: best people in the industry.  great culture.  successful organization
cons: decision making needs work...very concensus oriented

headline: Bright future of the company but employees are treated as commodity
pros:
Good salary, a lot of opportunities as there are always changes.  Management emphasizes on work/ life balance. 
Good products and well known within the industry
cons:
Reorganization 2 times a year, 3 times in 1.5 years, multiple waves of lay-off.
Poor management as they just want "ready-to-use" employees, no personal development, poor personal objectives set.

headline: Software Engineer II role at Vistaprint Digital
pros: Compensation, Benefits, Work/Life Balance, Culture
cons: Senior Management and Career Opportunities

headline: A growing company going through an exciting time
pros: Fast paced, steady improvements, focus on the customer, exciting strategy, strengthening leadership, growth opportunities
cons: difficult if averse to change, some parts of the company fewer growth opportunities

headline: Constant re-orgs and weak management
pros: Compensation is good and colleagues are smart.  Work can be interesting and can be cutting edge if in the right group.
cons: Constant re-orgs to the tune of 5+ per year gives the impression that management has no vision or plan and is demotivating to employees.  Complete removal of management training combined with bad managers leaves much to be desired.

headline: director of Engineering
pros: innovative and looking for new ideas everytime
cons: too many reorganizations, difficult to keep the people incentive and motivated

headline: Financial analyst
pros: Nice working environment, friendly colleagues, company focuses on the long term development.
cons: Paid time off is just ok. Many people said that company has great benefit, but I can't agree with it.

headline: Good people, challenging organization
pros: Benefits are great, people are generally smart and driven and nice to work with, many opportunities exist for moving up or to a different role
cons: They do a lot of re-organizations and as they have grown, upper management seems to have lost touch with the real folks who do the work

headline: Information Technology Manager
pros: Very positive upbeat environment,employees are empowered.  I love coming to work the people are all great.  Their recruiting process is unique and intense.
cons: Recently the bonus program was dropped and the dollar amount was added to our base salary.

headline: Operators
pros: Good place to work and pay the bills
cons: Decent work but constantly handling products and scaning different products all day and placing them in the bins

headline: Good pay, but bad environment for ambitious developers
pros: Decent salary and compensation, all-right benefits. Company is pretty good about work-life balance.
cons:
Company has a serious case of not-invented-here syndrome, and many of the software developers are long-timers who have never worked in another company, so the technological base and diversity is not very different from team to team. There is a very obvious tendency toward favoritism of people who have been with the company for significant periods of time, even if they don't have the best ideas.

Career growth for senior developers is very hazy and ill-defined. 

Company keeps trying to reinvent their process and internal organization, with very mixed results.

There is no real motivation for ambitious developers to do more than the base minimum - parts of the company just move so slowly or are so insular that high-achievers are going to be left very bored or feel like their work is unappreciated or pointless.

Technological leaders like to take point from companies with very questionable practices like Amazon.com, and implementing half-measures like bogus scrum.

headline: Fun place to work
pros: Lots of smart, fun people.
cons: Inexperienced senior leadership that could benefit from exposing themselves to more outside perspectives.

headline: Solid company to work for
pros:
I enjoy coming to work.  I feel like the company is stable but still striving to grow into new markets.  We're given the leeway to test, adopt new technologies and methodologies within our group as long as we meet our obligations.
I feel like work/life balance is good.  Getting time off for a family situation has never been a problem.  They also have a good number of events with and without families.
cons: It might just be coincidence or growing pains, but since I started at the company a couple years ago management has been re-structuring teams a lot.  Some defiantly for the better but sometimes less so.  Luckily my team has not been affected by this too much, but I have heard some people complain about it.

headline: Interesting Workplace
pros: Great People to work with
cons: Management needs to be re-evaluated

headline: Mostly good
pros: Great benefits, solid business, good people
cons: while teams are productive, the overall feeling is that there is not a lot of organization and "change management" is really poor.

headline: Very friendly MNC
pros: Friendly atmosphere,no dress code, flexible working hours, all get equal chance to grow.
cons: Wish to have free food n gym n other facilities.

headline: Program Manager
pros: Smart people to work with, Highly technical product, upper management mostly down to earth and approachable. Lots and lots of free food. Great benefits. Happy hour on thursdays and Fridays
cons: You are doomed if you are a minority person in management. Extreme arrogance in developers and architects. Company has a great way of attracting some top local talents but once in there they have no idea how to grow them. Extremely messed up organizational structure.

headline: Love working here
pros:
-Great atmosphere/Friendly environment
-Brand new building (literally built from the ground up). Has a good games room, covered parking, and gym.
-Very competitive pay compared to other offers I got
-Significant Discount at Vistaprint
-Biweekly Happy hour social 
-Free food truck food every other wednesday
cons: -Still little recognition as Cimpress

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Great perks, good bonus payouts, strong company, flex schedules available
cons: tough commute to Waltham, expected to be available in evenings

headline: Lead analyst
pros: Excellent  place to work. Great culture. Super smart people.
cons: Less visibility into management decisions

headline: Negative Impression of Cimpress
pros: Asked for input around employee branding strategy. Made people feel like part of the process...There was even some compensation tied to the winning strategy.
cons: Unfortunately, ideas were solicited and then there was never feedback to the individuals who submitted about who won this competition for an employee branding strategy/tag line, Until, that is, I saw my winning tag line appear on none other than glass door!!! Thanks, Cimpress. Classy move.

headline: Good experience. You have to be flexible to survive.
pros: Great exposure to work in a growing global business.  An opportunity to distinguish yourself in a changing environment and to own multiple projects.  Working with some very bright people that are constantly asking questions about how to improve.
cons: High turnover and multiple re-orgs make it a bumpy ride.  The plan is often that there is no plan but that we'll figure it out somehow. Some very inexperienced members of senior management in some departments.

headline: Reorg again?!
pros: Chance to watch a revolving door of management
cons: Leadership reorgs so much that it gets in the way of progress.

headline: Political
pros: Good work-life balance and a high rate of highly educated people.
cons: Very political although not a huge company yet.

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros: Challenging problems, good work life balance, new technologies
cons: Career structure is relatively flat, hard to rise up. Too many management people. (They do not restrict your work, just adds more overhead to projects)
